comments.commentBody:
This is perhaps the greatest tragedy in American life today, the lack of affordable housing. And this is not only in New York but everywhere. It will take more than a plan to build new "affordable" housing, it will take a nationwide effort on the part of administrations both at the federal and local levels to make this happen. Unaffordable housing is only a part of the demise of the middle class, and of the poor. Without having read the plan I can only suspect that it cannot possibly preserve affordable housing. I lived in New York for over 20 years and I could barely afford the rent. I did buy a house eventually but got divorced and turned the house over to my ex-spouse, a fair way to proceed. But I could never afford the rent then and certainly not now. Again, this is not happening only in New York City but everywhere. With stagnant wages, increasing demand for housing, this all spells the end for much of our way of life. I just read through the public review process and it is ridiculous.

"To many in East Harlem and other parts of the city where the working class and poor scrape by, construction means disruption, which inevitably means gentrification and dislocation. The rent always goes up, but they fear that the zoning changes will only make it rise faster and higher, inevitably making them exiles from their own city.' This says a lot. Yes, the poor and the working class scrape by.

The price of nuclear has been intentionally driven up by the addition of unneeded safety equipment and a pointless requirement for soldiers to guard the nuclear power plant [npp]. Guess Who? The coal industry is trying to put nuclear out of business by forcing nonsensical "safety" onto npp's. King Coal greatly fears nuclear, because on a level playing field, nuclear runs coal out of business very quickly.

Avoid closure of nuclear power plants by eliminating costly unnecessary safety measures. The coal industry pushes the nuclear "safety" issue to drive up the cost of nuclear power. Truth: Coal kills 3 million people every year and nuclear has killed zero in the US.

Example: Quit requiring that nuclear power plants [NPPs] be guarded by soldiers. There is no need for guards at a nuclear power plant because the reactor guards itself. There is no way a terrorist could steal reactor fuel from a reactor.

Stealing fuel from a reactor: So let me get this right: You want your terrorist to go inside the containment building and rob fuel from the reactor vessel? Your terrorist would die of radiation in 4 seconds. [So stay outside of the containment building.]

"Otherwise, we may find ourselves with a stockpile of radioactive waste with nowhere to safely store it. "

Ummmm.... We ALREADY have a stockpile of radioactive waste with nowhere to safely store it.

Ah, the siren call of nuclear power: unlimited, cheap, and clean - at least, that's what we were told in the early 1960s. Then, the reality of the resulting waste disposal issues crept in.

There are, of course, other options: wind, solar, hydrelectric, geothermal - and conservation. Wind and solar require efficient energy storage to be practical. Hydroelectric requires increasingly scarce water, and geothermal is only practical in certain geopraphic locations.

However, while we transition over to sustainable energy use from non-extractive sources, nuclear (with all its flaws) deserves a closer look. Given the past history of over-hyped benefits and disregard for obvious risks, I'd say we should give nuclear a very, very careful look before we leap. Otherwise, we may find ourselves with a stockpile of radioactive waste with nowhere to safely store it.
This is homegrown terrorism packaged and delivered by the unholy alliance of the GOP, NRA and far right Christians bigots.

This was fabulous! I followed the recipe to the letter using all three suggested lettuces, Cripps Pink apples, and feta cheese.  Such a wonderful contrast to all the heavy Thanksgiving food. But I won't wait until next Thanksgiving to make it again--this salad will be appearing on our dinner table quite often from now on.

The Government actually makes the money on the loans, Jane. There used to be Private lenders in the Federal Loan Program, but they were removed several years back because it was much more profitable for the Federal Government to make all the loans themselves. While there are Private Lenders still, that isn't what we're discussing here, and those loans only exist for those who cannot obtain Federal Loans (because they have defaulted on another debt, typically) and these loans are widely (correctly) seen as predatory. Nothing ends up in corporate pockets here. The government is the one benefiting and receiving the principal. do not worry.

Who is benefiting from the ballooning student loan problem? The borrowed principal ends up in the hands of academic institutions, using the student as a conduit, private lenders collect the interest, and the risk is borne by the taxpayers. Meanwhile, tuition costs have soared and students find their financial future (home ownership, children,even retirement) hobbled by debt.
Everything the government gives out ends somehow in corporate pockets.

Fantastic turkey! I dry-brined a 12lb turkey for 2 days, cooked exactly as directed (hard apple cider, white wine, etc., 1/2 hour at 450, 2 hours at 350) and it hit the temperature mark perfectly in every spot (at least 165 degrees). It was so well seasoned that no one added salt. Absolutely delicious. My first turkey, and I will be making it again next year. Thanks for the video, Melissa. I'm a visual learner and you gave me the confidence that this would be easy.

Student loans should come with a type of catastrophic risk insurance to protect the borrower from financial ruin should they encounter the kind of life challenges which Ms. Kelly faced. I find it incredibly remarkable that NO loan officer ever pointed out to her along the way about her mounting debts? Also, for an educated person, shouldn't she have had greater financial knowledge?
I live in Washington where marijuana is legal and we have the lowest gin violence in the country. Like we say here you need to smoke one and chill before you get to random conclusions
And this is being pro life?
¿QUEEN? ¡Sí!

Martin, from Wikipedia:

As to emigration (leaving their country), between 1880 and 1918 (World War I) many men left Slovenia to work in mining areas in other nations. Especially they chose to settle in the United States. The 1910 US Census showed that there were already "183.431 persons in the USA of Slovenian mother tongue." But there may have been many more, because a good number avoided anti-Slavic prejudice and "identified themselves as Austrians. Favorite localities before 1900 were Minnesota, Wisconsin, Michigan, as well as Omaha, Nebraska, Joliet, Illinois, Cleveland, Ohio, and rural areas of Iowa. After 1910, they settled in Utah (Bingham Copper Mine), Colorado (especially Pueblo), and Butte, Montana.

She is of the Joliet, Illinois sorts.

Reminds me of my Alsatian friends, half of whose family members were identified as Germans and half as French on the passenger manifests, although they had the same birth towns, family names, and traveled together.

Martin, first, I did the puzzle when Across Lite was not working  so that has put me in a fowl mood which means I am about to lay a jumbo egg.  The wife is a Slovene of sorts but that i not her picture. I guess the puzzle was okay. I'm sure it would be even better with AL.
LM, if shooting up a clinic and killing police officers with assault weapons aren't evidence of being disturbed, what would satisfy you?!  What person of sound mind would do this?

Perhaps we could wait for the investigation to be concluded before pronouncing what the motivation of the shooter was or wasn't all the speculation is of no use unless you are trying to accrue political points......

I would much rather know facts than argue supposition.....
Everyone should watch the PP hearings from several months ago. Very revealing as to just how disinformation can be dangerous to our society.
A great idea.

people shot and killed . . . all the time . . . without guns???

how's that happen? magic bullets?
Perhaps due to the number of dead, the span of the incidents in Paris, and the fact that a terrorist ORGANIZATION claimed responsibility?  Could those make the story more newsworthy?
You know the answers: white skin versus brown skin; Christians versus Muslims; Planned Parenthood versus restaurants and theaters; us versus them. You knew the answers all along.

Why does Paris terrorism span the NYT front page for weeks, and this US home-grown act of terrorism quickly drop to one column coverage below the fold? Does this paper mirror our society's indifference and resignation? We are shocked for the French. Where is our outrage for ourselves?

I said exactly the same thing in an email 3 days ago to CBS Radio here in metro New York. They ran a story about Planned Parenthood in Texas taking the state government to court. Then they mention that Planned Parenthood was under attack since a video came to light showing them to be selling fetal tissue. Then they went on to the next story. I pulled my car over and shut off an email telling them that if they are going to bring up the video which had nothing to do with what was going on in Texas then as responsible journalist they need to also say that Planned Parenthood was vindicated and the video was shown to have been heavily edited and skewed buy an antiabortion group.  It is bad journalism to keep reminding people of it when it was a fabrication.

I have a problem with the information in this sentence: The shooting came at a time when Planned Parenthood has been criticized because of surreptitious videos made by anti-abortion groups of officials discussing using fetal organs for research."

If you are going to bring up the video you need to add that it was deliberately, and misleadingly edited propaganda. "Surreptitious" Is the least of it.

In doing so, those opposed to such violence play right into the hands of those who would perpetrate it. All the "thoughts and prayers" in the world do nothing for the victims. But shutting down legitimate debate only shields the criminal.

Ignorance is bliss, perhaps?

and will you support increased taxes for improved prenatal care, and pre school and after  school programs that will allow people to work who have children? what about free lunches, or education? probably not. Those lives only matter in the uterus. Once out- you could care less.

to KMW: Unfortunately- this "is' the face of the current pro-life movement. Your position is now, in the minority. The vitriol that has accompanied the movement has de-legitimized it- turned it into a narrowly focused  obsession without any compassion for that "life" outside the womb; helped to feed the frenzy of punitive legislation and almost war on poor families who opt out of abortion as an option.
Not to mention the autonomy of women!
They are right there with all the Muslims denouncing jihadists.
I think it's awesome that they took him alive.   Luckily for him, he was white.

I do not know if the NYT review board will allow me to respond, as they have not allowed me to comment on others statements. But, here it goes.
You appear to have taken a portion of my statement out of context to further your response. Obviously comment sections are for readers to have their say. But my point, if read in its entirety, was that they are making statements based on assumed facts. This is not necessarily a wise thing to do.
Further, I have no disagreement with you that the actions were extreme. I simply do not believe that it is appropriate to assert motives, i.e., Christian extremism, to his actions. I honestly believe that it is best to wait until you find out his motives rather than insert your opinion of what they may be.
Rest assured, many a preacher will praise this killer come Sunday. Not all, by any means; not even a majority. But some will.
